revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[Image:Flag of the Solomon Islands.svg|right|thumb|The Flag of Solomon Islands]] [[Image:LocationSolomonIslands.png|thumb|The location of [[Solomon Islands]]]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Solomon Islands: '''[[Solomon Islands]]''' is a sovereign [[Melanesia]]n island nation located in the [[South Pacific Ocean]] south-east of [[Papua New Guinea]].{{cite web | date=13 July 2009 | url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bp.html | title=Solomon Islands | work=[[The World Factbook]] | publisher=United States [[Central Intelligence Agency]] | accessdate=23 July 2009}} The country is composed of nearly one thousand islands of the [[Solomon Islands (archipelago)|Solomon Islands archipelago]], which cover a total land area of {{convert|27540|km2|mi2}}. The capital is [[Honiara]], located on the island of [[Guadalcanal]]. The Solomon Islands archipelago is believed to have been inhabited by [[Melanesia]]n people for thousands of years. Some of the most bitter fighting of [[World War II]] occurred in the [[Solomon Islands campaign]] of 1942–45, including the [[Battle of Guadalcanal]]. Self-government was achieved in 1976 and independence two years later. The country is a [[Commonwealth realm]]. The historical [[North Solomon Islands]] covered [[Bougainville Province|Bougainville Island]], [[Choiseul Island|Choiseul]], [[Isabel Province|Santa Isabel]], the [[Shortland Islands|Shortlands]] and [[Ontong Java Atoll|Ontong Java]] and were largely under German control until 1900. The southern Solomon Islands, which included [[Guadalcanal]], [[Nggela Islands|the Nggelas]], [[Gizo, Solomon Islands|Gizo]], [[Kolombangara]], [[Marovo Island]], [[Mborokua]], [[New Georgia]], [[Vella Lavella]], [[Vangunu]], [[Rennell Island|Rennell]], [[Bellona Island|Bellona]], [[Makira]], [[Malaita]], [[Temotu Province|Temotu]] and a number of associated smaller islands were under British control and in 1893 became the [[British Solomon Islands|British Solomon Islands Protectorate]]. In 1945, Bougainville, and some associated minor islands, were transferred away from the protectorate to Australian administration and then in 1970 became a part of [[Papua New Guinea]]. The remainder stayed under the protectorate until independence in 1978 at which point they were officially named ''Solomon Islands''. All of the north and south Solomon Islands taken together are generally referred to as ''[[Solomon Islands (archipelago)|the Solomon Islands]]'' to distinguish them from the nation state of ''Solomon Islands''. Since 1998, ethnic violence, government misconduct, and crime have undermined stability and civil society. In June 2003 an Australian-led "multinational" force, the [[Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands]] (RAMSI), arrived to restore peace and disarm ethnic militias.[http://www.ramsi.org/about.html "What is RAMSI?"], RAMSI {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == General reference == [[Image:Solomon Islands-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|The whole of [[Solomon Islands]], click to enlarge]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: * Common English country name: [[Solomon Islands]] * Official English country name: Solomon Islands * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Solomon Island]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Solomon Islands]] * [[ISO country codes]]: SB, SLB, 090 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:SB]] * Internet [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.sb]] == Geography of Solomon Islands == [[Image:Guadalcanal Topography.png|thumb|Topographical map of the island of [[Guadalcanal]], click to enlarge]] [[Geography of the Solomon Islands]] The term ''the Solomon Islands'' refers to the group of islands that includes the islands of the nation state ''Solomon Islands'' but also other islands such as Bougainville, a province of Papua New Guinea. ''The Solomon Islands'' was the name given to this wider group of geographical islands by the British administration up to the independence of Solomon Islands in 1978; this article concerns itself with the political entity, the nation state of Solomon Islands. * Solomon Islands is... ** a country *** an [[island country]] *** a [[nation state]] *** a [[Commonwealth realm]] *** consists of an [[archipelago]] * Location: ** [[Southern Hemisphere]] and [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** Pacific Ocean *** [[South Pacific Ocean]] **** Oceania ***** [[Melanesia]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[UTC+11]] ** Extreme points of Solomon Islands *** High: [[Mount Popomanaseu]] on [[Guadalcanal]] {{convert|2335|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[South Pacific Ocean]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: ''none'' ** Coastline: [[South Pacific Ocean]] 5,313 km * [[Population of Solomon Islands]]: * * [[Area of Solomon Islands]]: * [[:commons:Atlas of the Solomon Islands|Atlas of Solomon Islands]] === Environment of Solomon Islands === [[Image:Choiseul Island NASA.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Choiseul Island]]]] * [[Climate of the Solomon Islands]] * [[Renewable energy in the Solomon Islands]] * [[Geology of the Solomon Islands]] * [[Protected areas of the Solomon Islands]] ** [[List of biosphere reserves in the Solomon Islands|Biosphere reserves in the Solomon Islands]] ** [[List of national parks of the Solomon Islands|National parks of Solomon Islands]] * [[Wildlife of the Solomon Islands]] ** [[Fauna of the Solomon Islands]] *** [[List of birds of the Solomon Islands archipelago|Birds of the Solomon Islands archipelago]] *** [[List of mammals of the Solomon Islands|Mammals of the Solomon Islands]] ==== Natural geographic features of Solomon Islands ==== * [[List of islands of Solomon Islands|Islands of Solomon Islands]] * [[List of lakes in the Solomon Islands|Lakes of the Solomon Islands]] * [[List of mountains of the Solomon Islands|Mountains of the Solomon Islands]] ** [[List '''Philip Jackson Darlington, Jr.''' (14 November 14 1904, [[Philadelphia]] – 16 December 1983, [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]) was an American entomologist, field naturalist, biogeographer, museum curator, and zoology professor. He was legendary for his collecting ability and his toughness and determination on field expeditions.<ref name=NAS>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/darlington-jackson.pdf|title=P. Jackson Darlington, Jr. 1904–1983, A Biographical Memoir|publisher=National Academy of Sciences|author=Wilson, Edward O.|authorlink=E. O. Wilson|year=1991}}</ref><ref name=Ball>{{cite book|editor=Ball, George E.|editorlink=George Ball (entomologist)|title=Taxonomy, Phylogeny and Zoogeography of Beetles and Ants: A Volume Dedicated to the Memory of Philip Jackson Darlington, Jr. 1904–1983|year=1985|publisher=Springer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mJ7LYqLodSsC}}</ref>
==Biography== Darlington graduated in 1922 from secondary school at [[Phillips Exeter Academy]] and then attended [[Harvard University]], where he graduated with bachelor's degree in 1926 and M.S. in 1927. In the 1920s he went on several field expeditions to the West Indies. From 1928 to 1929 he worked as an entomologist for the [[United Fruit Company]] near [[Santa Marta, Colombia]]. He returned to graduate study at Harvard University with an extensive collection of insects and vertebrates, including a diversity of bird skins, which formed the basis for a 1931 article.<ref name=NAS/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Notes on the birds of Rio Frio (near Santa Marta), Magdalena, Colombia|journal=Bulletin of the Museum of Comparative Zoology|year=1931|pages=349–421}}</ref> He received in 1931 his Ph.D. from Harvard University with a thesis on the ''[[Carabidae]]'' (ground beetles) of New Hampshire.<ref name=NAS/> From 1931 to 1932 he was a member of the [[Harvard Australian Expedition (1931–1932)]] led by [[William Morton Wheeler]] and returned with a collection of a huge number of insects and 341 mammals.<ref>{{cite book|author=Capinera, John L.|chapter=Darlington, Jr., Philip J|title=Encyclopedia of Entomologists|year=2008|pages=1153–1154|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ITMiiohVQC&pg=PA1153}}</ref><ref>Annual report of the director of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard College, to the president of Harvard College for 1932-1933. Cambridge, U.S.A.: Printed for the Museum p.54-58 [BHL - https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/41109461#page/58/mode/1up]</ref>
Darlington was a key member of the six-man [[Harvard Australian Expedition (1931-1932)]] sent on behalf of the [[Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology]] (MCZ)<ref>{{cite book|author=Capinera, John L.|chapter=Darlington, Jr., Philip J|title=Encyclopedia of Entomologists|year=2008|pages=1153–1154|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ITMiiohVQC&pg=PA1153}}</ref><ref>A Guide to Stag Beetles of Australia By George Hangay, Roger de Keyzer (p. 139) - https://books.google.com/books?id=CqxWDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139&dq=Harvard+expedition+to+Australia+in+1931&source=bl&ots=z7sMfkRcr3&sig=F82aRX9ZWuNqujfCXBHj90YFs5A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt3Kq1_K3bAhWB7lMKHW0uAJ8Q6AEIWTAF#v=onepage&q=Harvard%20expedition%20to%20Australia%20in%201931&f=false</ref> for the dual purpose of procuring specimens - the museum being "weak in Australian animals and...desires[ing] to complete its series" - and to engage in "the study of the animals of the region when alive."<ref>Nature International Journal of Science No. 3228, VOL. 128 - https://www.nature.com/articles/128457c0.pdf</ref><ref>A Guide to Stag Beetles of Australia By George Hangay, Roger de Keyzer (p. 139) - https://books.google.com/books?id=CqxWDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139&dq=Harvard+expedition+to+Australia+in+1931&source=bl&ots=z7sMfkRcr3&sig=F82aRX9ZWuNqujfCXBHj90YFs5A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt3Kq1_K3bAhWB7lMKHW0uAJ8Q6AEIWTAF#v=onepage&q=Harvard%20expedition%20to%20Australia%20in%201931&f=false</ref> The mission was success with over 300 mammal and thousands of insect specimens returning to the United States.<ref>{{cite book|author=Capinera, John L.|chapter=Darlington, Jr., Philip J|title=Encyclopedia of Entomologists|year=2008|pages=1153–1154|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ITMiiohVQC&pg=PA1153}}</ref><ref>About the Exhibits by Elizabeth Hall and Max Hall (Museum of Comparative Zoology "Agazziz Museum" Havard University. Third Edition, Copywrite 1964, 1975, 1985, by the President and Fellows of Harvard College</ref> His companion [[William E. Schevill]] reported that "Dr. Darlington's resourceful skill and industry had brought together, from New South Wales and Queensland, not only a large collection of insects, but also over three hundred fifty mammals, representing over sixty species, as well about fifty species of birds; in addition, he had about two hundred fifty reptiles and amphibians."<ref>Annual report of the director of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard College, to the president of Harvard College for 1932-1933. Cambridge, U.S.A.: Printed for the Museum p.54-58 [BHL - https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/41109461#page/58/mode/1up]</ref>
Following his return from the expedition, Darlington was made the MCZ's assistant curator of insects from 1932 to 1940,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.wku.edu/charles.smith/chronob/DARL1904.htm|title=Darlington, Philip Jackson, Jr.|website=people.wku.edu}}</ref> from 1940 to 1951 the [[Henry Clinton Fall]] Curator of Coleoptera, and from 1951 until his retirement in 1971 the Curator of Insects. He was also at Harvard University from 1962 until his retirement in 1971 the [[Alexander Agassiz]] Professor of Zoology.<ref name=NAS/>
Upon the entry of the Unites States into WW II, Darlington enlisted as a Sanitary Corps entomologist with the rank of first lieutenant in the [[United States Army Medical Service Corps]]. He served in the [[Sixth United States Army]] during [[Operation Cartwheel]] and subsequent campaigns before retiring as a major in April 1944. Before he departed from New Guinea, he was able to collect many specimens of ground beetles and other insects.<ref name=NAS/><ref name=Ball/>
In 1942 Darlington married Elizabeth Koch, who later accompanied on many of his field expeditions. The couple and their son, Philip Frederick Darlington, spent eighteen months in 1956–1957 for a field study, camping from a truck in the Australian outback.<ref name=NAS/>
==Scientific fame== Darlington presented a theory challenging [[William Diller Matthew]]'s 1915 theory of faunal dominance.<ref name=NAS/>
{{blockquote|Darlington's most important contribution to science was his theory of the Old World tropical origin of dominant vertebrate groups. He first sketched out this formulation—which would influence research in [[zoogeography]] for a generation—in The ''[[Quarterly Review of Biology]]'' of 1948, then presented it in full dress in his 1957 text, ''Zoogeography: The Geographical Distribution of Animals.''<ref name=NAS/>}}
==Episode with a crocodile== During a WW II field survey for malarial mosquito larvae in New Guinea, Darlington was sampling stagnant water. Collecting alone in the jungle, he ventured into a stagnant pool by stepping carefully onto a submerged log, but a full-grown crocodile swam up and attacked him. Although seized in the crocodile's jaws, he somehow managed by kicking the crocodile to escape and scramble back to land. Despite serious loss of blood, torn muscles and ligaments in both arms, broken bones in his right arm, and piercing wounds in both hands, he was able to hike back to the U.S. army hospital.<ref name=NAS/>
{{blockquote|With characteristic understatement, Darlington wrote to his wife of "an episode with a crocodile" but supplied no further details. He was in a cast for several months, convalescing at [[Girua Airport|Dobodura, Papua]], where he perfected a left-handed technique for collecting insects: Have someone tie a vial to the end of a stick. Walk out into the forest, jam the stick into the ground, pull the cork out with the left hand, drop the specimens into the vial, replace the cork. He eventually regained full use of his hands and arms.<ref name=NAS/>}}
==Frog drop experiment== [[Thomas Barbour]] was the director of Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology from 1927 to 1946. For many years, Barbour and Darlington had friendly arguments about Barbour's advocacy of faunal dispersion by land bridges versus Darlington's advocacy of exreme-wind-borne dispersal of small animals over isolated islands. To test his ideas, Darlington dropped several live frogs from a window on the fifth floor of the Museum. Barbour and a crowd of spectators observed the experiment. The dropped frogs were stunned and remained still for a few seconds, but almost immediately they started to recover and in a few minutes were hopping normally.<ref name=NAS/><ref name=Ball/>
==Awards and honors== * 1947 — Guggenheim Fellowship for the academic year 1947–1948<ref name=Guggenheim>{{cite web|title=Philip Jackson Darlington Jr.|website=John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|url=https://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/philip-jackson-darlington-jr/}}</ref> * 1956 — Guggenheim Fellowship for the academic year 1956–1957<ref name=Guggenheim/> * 1957 — [[Daniel Giraud Elliot Medal]] * 1962 — elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences<ref>{{cite book|title=Members of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences: 1780–2017|page=138|url=https://www.amacad.org/multimedia/pdfs/publications/bookofmembers/ChapterD.pdf}}</ref> * 1964 — elected a Member of the United States National Academy of Sciences
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Harvard|state=collapsed}}

{{no footnotes|date=January 2017}} [[File:Cantino planisphere (1502).jpg|thumb|500px|The [[Cantino planisphere]] (1502), copy of the Portuguese Padrão Real]]
The '''Padrão Real''' ({{IPA-pt|pɐˈðɾɐ̃w̃ ʁiˈaɫ}}, translated into English as ''Royal Pattern'') was a cartographic work of Portuguese mastery produced secretly and maintained by the organization of the Portuguese Royal Court in the 16th century. The work was available to the scientific elite of the time, being exposed in the [[Casa da Índia|Casa da Índia (House of India)]]. In the Padrão Real the new discoveries of the Portuguese were constantly added and mapped. The first Padrão Real was produced in the time of [[Prince Henry the Navigator|Henry the Navigator]], even before the existence of the Casa da Índia.
The Padrão Real of the House of India hung from the ceiling in the Division of Maps as the Portuguese masterpiece, extremely secretive and guarded of foreign spies and merchants.
The Padrão Real included the complete record of the Portuguese discoveries, public and secret. The House of India issued maps based on the Padrão Real to navigators in Royal service.
The [[Cantino planisphere]] (1502) is a copy of the Padrão Real, possibly produced by some Portuguese bribed cartographer. It is conjectured that Cantino was able to bribe a cartographer to copy the map between December 1501 and October 1502. From a letter signed by Cantino it is thought that he sent the map to the [[Duchy of Ferrara|Duke of Ferrara]] on November 19, 1502.
The Padrão Real was lost in time. However a copy (Cantino planisphere) still exists. The Spanish counterpart of the Portuguese Padrão Real was the [[Padrón Real]], officially established by the Spanish Monarchs in 1508, in the [[Casa de Contratación]].
==References== <references/> * ''[https://books.google.com.co/books?id=2zZCAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA53&dq=Note+on+the+Castiglioni+Planisphere&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjQoual3pLcAhVOu1MKHYqRD5IQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Note%20on%20the%20Castiglioni%20Planisphere&f=false Note on the Castiglioni Planisphere]'', Armando Cortesao, Imago Mundi, Vol. 11, 1954 (1954), pp. 53–55 * Harvey, Miles ''[https://books.google.com.co/books?id=Dyn5EsM0ibwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Island+of+Lost+Maps:+A+True+Story+of+Cartographic+Crime&hl=es-419&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk1vas3pLcAhVFuFMKHaRtAIQQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&q=The%20Island%20of%20Lost%20Maps%3A%20A%20True%20Story%20of%20Cartographic%20Crime&f=false The Island of Lost Maps: A True Story of Cartographic Crime]''. New York:[[Random House]], 2000. {{ISBN|0-7679-0826-0}}. (Also {{ISBN|0-375-50151-7}}).
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Padrao Real}} [[Category:Maps]] [[Category:Portuguese discoveries]] [[Category:Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:Maritime history of Portugal]] [[Category:Portugal in the Age of Discovery]]

revision.text:
[[File:Map of the Pearl Fishery Coast 1889.jpg|thumb|Map of the Pearl Fishery Coast, on the southeast portion of the Indian peninsula.]] [[Image:Conversion of Paravas by Francis Xavier in 1542.jpg|thumb|Conversion of the [[Paravas]] by [[Francis Xavier]], in a 19th-century colored lithograph.]] [[File:Vaipparfamily.JPG|thumb|Inhabitants of the Pearl Fishery Coast.]] The '''Pearl Fishery Coast''' refers to a coastal area of southern [[India]], extending along the [[Coromandel Coast]] from [[Tuticorin]] to [[Comorin]] ruled by [[Paravar]]s.<ref name="The Month 398">[https://books.google.com/books?id=eXFIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA398 ''The month'' Vol.66 p.398]</ref>
The coast took its name from the presence of [[pearls]] on the coast, and the numerous fisheries that operated to exploit them.<ref name="Indian church history review">"Among the coastal areas the Fishery Coast was famous because of the pearls found in it. Thousands of people were employed every season in pearl fishing. The Paravas and Muslims often fought for the ownership of the Pearl Fishery." in ''Indian church history review'' Vol.35 2001 p.70</ref>
In a conflict between the Paravas and the Arabs in 1532, the Paravas sought protection from the Portuguese. In 1535, the Portuguese led an army under [[Pedro Vaz (captain)|Pedro Vaz]] and expelled the Arabs.<ref name="Kim 103"/> As a compensation, the Paravas accepted to convert to Christianity.<ref name="Kim 103"/>
The Portuguese conquered the Pearl Fishery Coast from the Muslims of [[Kalyalpattanam]] in 1525.<ref name="Kim 103"/> They restored the rights of the Paravas to exploit their fisheries in exchange for a considerable annual tribute.<ref name="Kim 103"/>
The Paravas, who lived along the Pearl Fishery Coast adopted Christianity in 1535-1536, becoming an important Christian region, and succeeded the first introduction of Christianity in [[Mylapore]] with the [[Thomas Christians]].<ref name="Kim 103">[https://books.google.com/books?id=xa4vAejmG_AC&pg=PA103 ''Strange names of God'' Sangkeun Kim p.103''ff'']</ref> The Portuguese derived considerable profit from the pearl trade, and strictly controlled the Pearl Fishery Coast through the [[Padroado]] system.<ref name="Kim 103"/>
The missionary [[Francis Xavier]], coming from [[Goa]], reached the Pearl Fishery Coast in 1542, where he was able to evangelize successfully the [[Paravars]], converting an estimated 40,000 to 50,000 souls.<ref name="The Month 398"/>
In 1553, a fleet of the [[Ottoman Empire]] made a raid on the Pearl Fishery Coast around [[Tuticorin]]. They were assisted by the [[Marakkar]] [[Muslims]] of [[Zamorin|Malabar]], and had the tacit agreement of [[Vittula Nayak]] of [[Madurai]].<ref name="Malekandathil 117">''Maritime India-Trade, Religion and Polity In the Indian Ocean'' by Pius Malekandathil p.117 [https://books.google.com/books?id=rN69iFj1PJoC&pg=PA117]</ref> 52 Portuguese were captured at [[Punnaikayal]], and churches burnt down.<ref name="Malekandathil 117"/> The Ottomans failed however in 1553 against a Portuguese fleet at sea near [[al-Fahl]].<ref>''Historical Muscat: an illustrated guide and gazetteer'' John Peterson p.118 [https://books.google.com/books?id=gNu4_uHo7CQC&pg=PA118]</ref><ref>''Historical Muscat: an illustrated guide and gazetteer'' John Peterson p.48 [https://books.google.com/books?id=gNu4_uHo7CQC&pg=PA48]</ref>
There were numerous conflicts between the Christian Paravas and the Muslims for control of the fisheries.<ref name="Indian church history review"/>
==See also== * [[Industry in ancient Tamil country]] * [[Keelavaippar]] * [[Periathalai]] * [[Punnaikayal]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of India]] [[Category:1525 establishments in the Portuguese Empire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Political post |post = Prime Minister |body = the
Independent State of
Samoa |insignia = Coat of Arms Samoa.svg |insigniasize = 100px |insigniacaption = Coat of arms of
the Independent State
of Samoa |termlength = |image = Tuilaepa Aiono Sailele Malielegaoi 2014 (cropped).jpg |imagesize = 150px |incumbent = [[Tuilaepa Aiono Sailele Malielegaoi]] |incumbentsince = 23 November 1998 |appointer = [[Tufuga Efi]] |appointer_qualified = [[O le Ao o le Malo]] |formation = 22 May 1875 |inaugural = [[Albert Barnes Steinberger]] |website = }} {{Politics of Samoa}} The '''Prime Minister of Samoa''' is the [[head of government]] of the [[Samoa|Independent State of Samoa]], a sovereign country located in the [[Pacific Ocean]]. ==History of the office== The first Prime Minister of Samoa was [[Albert Barnes Steinberger]], who originally represented the [[United States|American]] [[United States federal government|government]] in the [[Samoan Islands]] but was close to [[German Empire|German]] commercial interests. After the indigenous authorities of the islands adopted the Constitution of 1873, Steinberger was appointed Prime Minister by the King [[Malietoa Laupepa]] in July 1875. He hold this post for seven months before the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] and American consuls in the country persuaded Laupepa to dismiss him, seeing his role as German interference in the islands. Over the next two decades, there was no Prime Minister in the country, and in 1899 Samoa fell under the colonial rule of the Western powers, being divided as [[German Samoa|a German colony]] and [[American Samoa|an American colony]] at the end of the [[Second Samoan Civil War]], according to the terms of the [[Tripartite Convention]].Malama Meleisea, ''Lagaga: A Short History of Western Samoa'', Apia, University of the South Pacific, 1987, {{ISBN|982-02-0029-6}}, pp.83-85 At the beginning of the [[World War I]], [[German Samoa]] was [[Occupation of German Samoa|occupied]] by [[New Zealand]] in 1914, and was subsequently organized as [[Western Samoa Trust Territory|a trust territory]] of New Zealand in 1920. The territory gained independence in 1962 as the Independent State of Samoa. The [[Constitution of Samoa|Constitution]], adopted in 1960 during the transitional period of autonomy, provides that the [[Executive (government)|executive power]] is vested in the [[head of state]] ([[O le Ao o le Malo]]), elected by the [[Legislative Assembly of Samoa|Legislative Assembly]], and who acts only on the recommendation of the government. The head of state has a ceremonial role. The real executive power is exercised by the Prime Minister and his [[Cabinet of Samoa|cabinet]]. The Prime Minister is appointed by the head of state as a member of the Legislative Assembly who enjoys the confidence of a majority in the Legislative Assembly (Article 32 (2) (a)). The Prime Minister may be removed from office by the Legislative Assembly (Article 33 (1) (b)). Samoa is thus a [[parliamentary democracy]] based on the [[Westminster system]].[http://www.samlii.org/ws/legis/consol_act/cotisos1960438/ Constitution of Samoa] ==List of Prime Ministers of Samoa (1875–present)== {{Officeholder table start | showorder = y | showimage = y | officeholder_title = Prime Minister | showtermlenght = y | party_col = 1 | showaltofficeholder = y | alt_officeholder_title = [[O le Ao o le Malo|''{{nowrap|O le Ao o le Malo}}''

[[Malietoa Tanumafili II|Tanumafili II]] }} {{Officeholder table | order2 = 3 | image = blank.png | military_rank = [[Tupua Tamasese]] | officeholder = [[Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV|Lealofi IV]] |
